entry.title: Issue in configuring Post Quiz Navigation in Enable Now
entry.content:
We are experiencing a challenge with post-quiz navigation in SAP Enable Now. Currently, when launching a quiz from the launch page (bookpage) inside a BOOK, after quiz completion (clicking the close button on the quiz evaluation), the navigation returns the user to the same launch page.

Our requirement is:

  • If the quiz is passed, the user should be redirected to Congratulations page (next to launch page).
  • If the quiz is failed, the user should remain on the Launch page.

However, we are unable to configure this scenario and need assistance in implementing conditional navigation based on quiz results.

Please advise on the correct configuration or provide guidance on resolving this issue.

entry.title: Issue for 261 while confirmation using BAPI_PROCORDCONF_CREATE_HDR
entry.content:
Hi, 
I am doing confirmation using the function module BAPI_PROCORDCONF_CREATE_HDR for process order and have selected for backflushing.
But only 101 is done, and 261 is not.
 
Below are the data I am passing :-
APPEND INITIAL LINE TO athdrlevels ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL (<athdrlevels>).
 <athdrlevels>-orderid    = lv wet_cake_order.
 <athdrlevels>-fin_conf   = abap_true.
 <athdrlevels>-clear_res  = abap_true.
 <athdrlevels>-postg_date = sy-datum.
 <athdrlevels>-conf_text  = 'Auto confirmed'.
 <athdrlevels>-yield = v_calc_qty.
 
APPEND INITIAL LINE TO goodsmovements ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL (<goodsmovements>).
 <goodsmovements>-material  = is_resb-matnr.
 <goodsmovements>-plant     = ls_order_header-werks.
 <goodsmovements>-move_type = '101'.
 <goodsmovements>-entry_qnt = lv_calc_qty.
 <goodsmovements>-orderid   = 1v_wet_cake_order.
 <goodsmovements>-mvt_ind   = 'F'.
 
APPEND INITIAL LINE TO link_conf_goodsmov ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL (<link_conf_goodsmov>).
 <link_conf_goodsmov>-index_confirm = '1'. 
 <link_conf_goodsmov>-index_gm_depend = '1'.
 <link_conf_goodsmov>-index_goodsmov = '1'.
 
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PROCORDCONF_CREATE_HDR'        "#EC CI_USAGE_OK[2438131]
   EXPORTING
post_wrong_entries = '2'
   IMPORTING
return = ls_return
   TABLES
athdrlevels = athdrlevels
goodsmovements = goodsmovements
link_conf_goodsmov = link_conf_goodsmov
detail_return = detail_return.
 
IF NOT line_exists( detail_return[ type = 'A' ] ) AND
   NOT line_exists( detail_return[ type = 'E' ] ) AND
   NOT line_exists( detail_return[ type = 'X' ] ).
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI TRANSACTION COMMIT
  EXPORTING
wait abap_true.
ENDIF.
 
Suggest any changes or need to add anythig else.
 
Regards 
jitendra

entry.title: STOs Not Receiving Confirmation Dates Despite Available Stock
entry.content:
The STOs from plant are not getting a proper confirmed date. Even when stock or future receipts are available, the system keeps giving 31.12.9999. At the same time, Sales Orders created later are getting confirmed dates correctly for the same material. ATP is clearly seeing the stock because CO09 shows the quantities, but the STOs still don’t receive a valid commitment. This used to work earlier, where STO and SO priorities were treated the same, but now the STOs seem to be losing out. Some STOs even have stock allocated but still show 9999, which means the date calculation itself is failing. Since a custom BOP program is used for plant , something in master data or custom logic seems to have changed, so we’re checking both.

 

please help here

entry.title: Re: Create outbound delivery based on inbound delivery or inbound DESADV IDoc
entry.content:
Hello,
Could you please share how you resolved the issue related to Custom Inbound Processing? I’m facing the exact same challenge with an automotive client.

In our case, the supplier (my project client) follows a specific business process: they perform a stock transfer to an external forwarding agent without creating an invoice. The forwarding agent then delivers the goods directly to the customer and sends an ASN both to the customer and back to the supplier. Based on this ASN from the forwarding agent, the system should automatically create the outbound delivery.

I would really appreciate any insights on how you handled this scenario.

Ayoub,

entry.title: Re: How can I activate LZM + TAM combination in SAP Publi...
entry.content:
Dear @Toma44,

In Public Cloud you generally can’t activate the ECC automotive pair LZM (SA with delivery orders), TAM (delivery order) as a dedicated document-flow chain the way you know it from ECC. That LZM/TAM flow is a classic Scheduling Agreements with Delivery Orders concept from SAP Private /on-premise documentation, not a Public Cloud scope-item switch.

What you can do in Public Cloud and still keep cumulative quantities + traceability:

Option A: Scope item 3NR Sales Scheduling Agreements

This is the Public Cloud-supported way to run automotive-style SSA processes with cumulative quantities and follow-on logistics without a TAM layer. Sales Scheduling Agreements in Public Cloud explicitly support cumulative quantities

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/e092ba53422bb54ce10000000a174cb4.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/cd256a63aba744f48cca682610f6fbeb.html

How to activate:

  1. Add scope item 3NR
  2. In the Pubic Cloud system use the scheduling agreement apps (create/change/display) and set up delivery schedule processing

Integration / EDI note (important for automotive):
Public Cloud typically expects delivery schedule integration via the provided services (not classic IDoc processing). The Delivery Schedule of Sales Scheduling Agreement interface exists for receiving/updating delivery schedules

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/03c04db2a7434731b7fe21dca77440da/837a0869882f4344b121f26e0adf144f.html

Cumulative quantity corrections:
If you ever need to realign cumulative figures, Public Cloud supports correcting cumulative delivered quantities via correction deliveries in the scheduling agreement context

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/2619d667d79b4ac9bd156fb6b3a8dfe8.html

Resulting document flow:
Sales Scheduling Agreement ->Outbound Delivery->PGI->Billing
Your cumulative quantities are tracked on the scheduling agreement so you still get the control you need JUST without a TAM document in between

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/e092ba53422bb54ce10000000a174cb4.html

Option B: Scope item 2EM Just-In-Time Supply to Customer

If your TAM usage is really about JIT execution, check whether your target process is actually 2EM Just-In-Time Supply to Customer which is explicitly positioned for JIT supply scenarios

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2bba750d1e124e1ea2a039bb1cd9b6c5/bb8cc89be15e44d3abbe35a399904b3c.html

Summary:

  • Exact ECC-like LZM->TAM activation not available as a Public Cloud scope-item feature
  • Closest supported Public Cloud design activate 3NR and optionally 2EM if you do JIT, then run SSA->Outbound Delivery with cumulative quantities on the SSA

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: LMS: How to share class (video) recordings to employees after completion?
entry.content:
Hello community,

Does anyone have experience with sharing documents or recordings after class completion?

We hoped we could add a Document Link to the completed class, but bumped into an issue here: After an administrator or instructor marked class completion for class attendees, the item will appear in someone's learning history. In the details of the learning history record, we can retrieve the Class ID. Further the learner can access the item, but they can't access the specific class that they completed. That means that the document link is unaccessable to them. 

Does anyone of you have experience with workarounds? 

Thank you!

CKME

  • In CKME, I entered the Material, Plant, selected "Prices Flagged from Actual Costing", and provided the costing run, period, and application used in the corresponding CKMLCP execution.

  • Is it necessary to check the Costing Variant as well?

entry.title: Start your SAP Cloud ALM journey – build a PoC for manual testing
entry.content:
Are you looking for a simple way to begin your SAP Cloud ALM journey? Manual testing is one of the easiest adoption use cases. To help you take that first step, we’ve created a dedicated guide to help you build a Proof of Concept (PoC) and gain hands-on experience with manual testing in SAP Cloud ALM.

Why Start with Manual Testing?

Manual Testing is a great first use case for SAP Cloud ALM because:

  • No complex setup required – you can get started quickly without needing to configure integrations or environments.
  • Standalone functionality – Manual testing can be used independently, making it ideal for teams who want to explore SAP Cloud ALM without committing to a full implementation right away.
  • Easy next step for Solution Manager users – once you’ve transferred your test case content via Selective Data Transfer, manual testing lets you immediately begin working with that data in SAP Cloud ALM.
  • Simple upload from Excel or other sources – teams managing test cases outside of SAP can easily bring them into Cloud ALM via Excel template upload.
  • Immediate value – it helps teams experience core functionality and benefits of SAP Cloud ALM from day one.

Why the PoC Is Easy to Execute

The guide is designed to help you quickly validate manual testing in SAP Cloud ALM with minimal effort:

  • Provided test case content – use included best practice data to simulate realistic testing scenarios without needing to create your own test case content upfront.
  • Role-based step-by-step instructions – follow clear guidance tailored to the roles involved in testing, making it easy to understand and execute.
  • Fast and flexible – the PoC can be completed in just a few hours and even simulated by a single person for initial validation, before scaling to involve the full team.

What activities are included in the PoC?

  • Uploading and preparing test cases
  • Using SAP Best Practice test scripts (available for S/4HANA Cloud)
  • Creating and managing test plans
  • Executing manual test cases
  • Monitoring and processing defects
  • Experiencing how reporting and analytics supports the entire process

Ready to Begin?

View the Guide for building a PoC for manual testing in SAP Cloud ALM.pdf to get started – your first step toward confident, cloud-based manual testing.

Feedback is appreciated! Please share any suggestions or questions in the comments so the guide can be improved. Thank you!

entry.title: The Future of Supply Chain Management | Part 5 of 6
entry.content:
Supply Chain 2035: The New Era of Logistics: AI and Robotics in Action?

Part 5 of the “Supply Chain of the Future” series focuses on transportation and warehouse logistics where speed, reliability, and transparency determine costs, service, and resilience. The joint study by SAP Business Consulting and Kühne Logistics University clearly shows that companies who tightly integrate their processes digitally can prevent bottlenecks, reduce costs, and increase service levels. At the same time, however, the survey also makes it clear that the ambitions of many companies in the field of transport and warehouse logistics for 2035 are surprising – less because the technologies are lacking, but because their implementation is difficult alongside current operational challenges.

Global competitive pressure is increasing, and the pressure to act in terms of efficiency and cost optimization remains high. Energy, transport and staff are becoming more expensive, growth stimuli in the industrial sector are scarce in many developed countries, and efficiency is no longer achieved incidentally. Even small improvements in lead times, utilization, or error rates have an immediate impact on delivery dates and costs. In manufacturing companies, logistics is the backbone of stable processes, and standstill is therefore not an option. At the same time, the shortage of skilled workers often exacerbates the pressure to act: In Germany and other countries, jobs in warehouses and transport are increasingly difficult to fill, especially where processes are still lived manually and fragmented.

Tasks must be solved differently in the future – through higher automation, targeted assistance systems, the use of AI, and the courageous rethinking of processes. Against the backdrop of increased pressure to act, the results of a survey conducted in April 2025 show a mixed picture: 39 percent of respondents expect significantly stronger digitalization and data-driven warehouse processes with significant advances in responsiveness and transparency by 2035. 28 percent expect the use of advanced technologies such as autonomous vehicles or drones in transport and material flow scenarios; another 28 percent see AI agents as integral support tools for dispatchers, warehouse managers and drivers. In addition, 20 percent expect connected ecosystems with real-time data exchange across company boundaries. So, the direction is clear, but expectations seem moderate compared to the technological perspectives and already existing use cases. One of the possible reasons: the vision exists, but there is often a lack of clear implementation plans, as time, know-how and resources are scarce. Many companies are lagging behind with the modernization of their processes and systems and can therefore integrate the potential of innovative technologies and real-time data into their daily work and decision-making to the required extent.

At the same time, the survey reveals weaknesses in the current situation: Only 17 percent of the 180 surveyed companies use real-time data comprehensively to optimize warehousing. Only 9 percent are committed to real-time transparency in the transportation sector with accurate arrival time forecasts, and only 6 percent have established collaborative planning and execution models with partners. It is positive to mention that 19% of companies have already gained initial experience with generative AI – so this is a new field where progress has been made. Overall, however, the figures show that the comprehensive implementation of digital innovations in practice still falls significantly short of the possibilities.

What needs to be done? Successful innovation requires a clear, prioritized strategy and readiness to adapt processes and technologies, supported by comprehensive and high-quality data, intelligent analytics, and effective orchestration. On the one hand, a resilient digital backbone which integrates process and sensor data into a consistent situational picture across transport, yard and warehouse is required. Orchestration within the company as well as data exchange across company boundaries is crucial. This data forms the basis for AI-driven decision logic, such as predictive ETA forecasts, dynamic capacity and slot controls, and anomaly detection. AI agents should perform routine tasks, structure exceptions, and provide appropriate options for action. In addition, AI technologies are increasingly moving into physical logistics processes, where many experts expect further groundbreaking developments – both in the software and hardware sectors. This includes increasingly flexible robots and cobots paired with innovative business models (e.g., renting robots to flexibly absorb seasonal peaks). Fast integration and the ability to up- and downscale these solutions within existing systems are crucial.

To achieve the transition to innovative technologies and processes, it is essential to proactively address cultural resistance and implement effective change management. To drive innovation at every level of the business, leaders must deliver a holistic vision and actively involve employees in the change process. An open communication culture and continuous training of employees help to create a positive environment in which technological innovations are accepted.

Why do ambitions remain subdued? Many companies are running multiple transformation projects at the same time. Logistics is still often seen as a pure cost center and shifts backwards in priority – although it often delivers quick and measurable effects. The first step to systematically unlocking this potential can be, for example, to develop an innovation roadmap, depending on the business context. This identifies clear areas of action and bottlenecks and links business goals with the appropriate technology choice: not only “Which robot?”, but “What problem, which flow, which bottleneck – and which measure scales across locations?".

Our appeal: start now rather than catch up too late. The technologies are up and running, there is a need for action, and market pressure is increasing. Understanding the implementation as a continuous process with a clear roadmap, iterative scaling, and measurable effects closes the gap between ambition and reality – and transforms logistics from an often more reactive element of the value chain into a strategic advantage.

Figure: Vision 2035 and Reality 2025 in Transportation and Logistics

 

This article was written in collaboration with Prof. Kai Hoberg (Kühne Logistics University) in the context of the SAP-KLU study "The Supply Chain of the Future”.

entry.title: How to Delete SAP IW22 Attachments Programmatically Using Binary Relations and SO_OBJECT_DELETE.
entry.content:
• Introduction

In Sap PM, Users frequently attach documents to notifications (IW22/IW23) However, there are scenarios where attachments need to be deleted 

1) Attachments uploaded by mistake

2) obsolete/outdated documents

Business Requirement

1) User enters notification number on selection screen

2) Program identifies attachments linked via GOS 

3) Retrieve link relationship ATTA

4) Delete Binary Relation entry

5)Delete SO Object(actual attachment from repository)

6) commit and confirm deletion

Technical Components

ComponentPurpose

Gos / BDS 

Attachment Management

CL_BINARY_RELATION=>READ_LINKS

Read Attachment Links

BINARY_RELATION_DELETE

Remove Relationship

SO_OBJECT_DELETE

Delete Document

Object Type

(Notification)

Relation Type

ATTA

Application Flow

1.user enters notification number(QMEL-QMNUM)
2.Program reads attachment links using BDS
3.Extract object A + Object B (Document references)
4.Delete Binary relation(ATTA)
5.Delete attachment file from sapoffice folder
6.commit work

Key ABAP Logic Implementation

Step – 1: Go to SE38 transaction code, Create Program, shown as below 

Step - 2: Click on Create and enter title description, type as Executable Program and Click on Save button. Then provide Package and request number. 

Step-3 Declare all data declarations for tables

Step– 4: Define Parameters for user input

Step- 5 : Define the Notification number, Instid, Typeid, and Catid to get attachment.

Step- 6 : using standard method (cl_binary_relation=>read_links) to get attachment from iw22 based on notification number

 

Step-7 : using call function (BINARY_RELATION_DELETE) to delete Delete a Binary Relationship

Step-8 Assigning values to (SO_OBJECT_DELETE) to Deleting an object from a folder

 

 

 

 

Execution Flow

🔹Step 1: Enter Notification Number

🔹Step 2: Execute Program to Delete Attachment & Check IW22 Attachments → Confirm Deletion


 

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZTEST_DELETE_ATTCH
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Deleting IW22 attachments using custom ABAP program
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT ztest_delete_attch.

DATA : ls_object_a  TYPE borident,
       ls_object_b  TYPE borident,
       ls_folder_id TYPE soodk,
       ls_object_id TYPE soodk,
       ls_lpor      TYPE sibflporb,
       ls_relst     TYPE obl_s_relt,
       lt_relst     TYPE obl_t_relt,
       lt_list      TYPE obl_t_link.

FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_list> TYPE obl_s_link.

SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b1 WITH FRAME TITLE text-001.
PARAMETERS: p_no TYPE qmel-qmnum OBLIGATORY.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b1.

" Prepare the logical object
ls_lpor-instid = p_no.
ls_lpor-typeid = 'BUS2038'.
ls_lpor-catid  = 'BO'.

" Relation filter: ATTA → Attachments
ls_relst-sign   = 'I'.
ls_relst-option = 'EQ'.
ls_relst-low    = 'ATTA'.
APPEND ls_relst TO lt_relst.

" Read document links
CALL METHOD cl_binary_relation=>read_links
  EXPORTING
    is_object           = ls_lpor
    it_relation_options = lt_relst
  IMPORTING
    et_links            = lt_list.

" Read first attachment
READ TABLE lt_list ASSIGNING <fs_list> INDEX 1.
IF sy-subrc = 0 AND <fs_list> IS ASSIGNED.

  ls_object_a-objkey  = <fs_list>-instid_a.
  ls_object_a-objtype = <fs_list>-typeid_a.
  ls_object_b-objkey  = <fs_list>-instid_b.
  ls_object_b-objtype = <fs_list>-typeid_b.

  " Delete relationship
  CALL FUNCTION 'BINARY_RELATION_DELETE'
    EXPORTING
      obj_rolea    = ls_object_a
      obj_roleb    = ls_object_b
      relationtype = 'ATTA'.

  " Prepare folder object for deletion
  ls_folder_id-objtp = <fs_list>-instid_b+0(3).
  ls_folder_id-objyr = <fs_list>-instid_b+3(2).
  ls_folder_id-objno = <fs_list>-instid_b+5(12).

  ls_object_id-objtp = <fs_list>-instid_b+17(3).
  ls_object_id-objyr = <fs_list>-instid_b+20(2).
  ls_object_id-objno = <fs_list>-instid_b+22(12).

  " Delete document from repository
  CALL FUNCTION 'SO_OBJECT_DELETE'
    EXPORTING
      folder_id = ls_folder_id
      object_id = ls_object_id.

  COMMIT WORK AND WAIT.
ENDIF.

 

Conclusion

This program automatically deletes attachments from iw22 notifications

entry.title: Re: Issue with Withholding Tax Codes Not Appearing in DRC...
entry.content: In the current SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Colombia localization), withholding tax codes are not exposed in the Configure Value Mapping app. The app is designed to handle VAT tax codes for DIAN electronic invoicing. Withholding taxes (RETE‑IVA, RETE‑ICA, ICA, Autorretección, etc.) are managed through the Extended Withholding Tax configuration in CBC and are not part of the DRC value mapping catalog. This is why you only see VAT codes available for mapping.  Check this SAP Help Overview of Settings for Withholding Tax

entry.title: Enriching Data from Infotype 2010 for Award Interpretation in EC Payroll
entry.content:
Introduction

With SuccessFactors EC and EC Payroll, a lot of the burden on Payroll has dissipated, when it comes to having custom Infotypes, dynamic actions and custom operations and functions. Specifically, for any core-HR customisation, the onus is on custom MDFs and portlets in EC; for any time-based custom award interpretation, the onus of driving it is on SF Time Management.

However, when rostering and timesheeting are part of the larger payroll solution, and the system architecture includes non-SAP applications such as UKG, WFS or others, there is a possibility that some award interpretation may be beyond the capabilities of the leading time system. In such cases, the EC Payroll system has to house the custom logic in some form. SAP’s official position on EC Payroll is for it to only have the Payroll engine running and hence, it is hamstrung when it comes to having a custom ABAP program running for non-payroll logic or even having time evaluation running in ECP.

An example of this is below, where the legislation and consequently the Award/CBA/Enterprise Agreement is geared towards automation in the payroll system to pay a percentage of the earnings of an employee on the day.

Figure 1 Example of a Time-based payment legislative guideline

 

Analysis

EC Payroll gets timesheet data from WFS / UKG / other leading time system which has a record for an employee to get paid this allowance for 1 Unit or say 8 Hours. The payroll schema rolls up all the amounts it needs to pay for the period and at this point, it doesn’t feel the need to carry day-by-day totals of hours or amounts.

The timesheet system can’t do this “calculation” outright because it doesn’t know the rate. EC Payroll can’t do this calculation because it doesn’t have day-by-day hours and if the rate is different on different days, then it’s a no-starter.

Traditionally, when EC Payroll needs day-by-day totals, there are 3 options to achieve it:

  1. Time Evaluation (PT60) is run. This needs Infotype 2010 data in time evaluation, which can only be brought into SAP Time Management by a custom operation. There are other overheads such as configuration of time management groupings, time types and collision indicators and a whole time schema to contend with. Payroll administrators are also tasked with the extra responsibility of kicking off PT60 every time they want to run payroll and analyse its errors.
  2. A custom function or operation is written in EC Payroll to fetch and create a structure (similar to ZL) to house day-by-day numbers and amounts. This needs detailed functional specifications, and implementation of robust ABAP code that is able to withstand retros and offcycles.
  3. Throw in the towel ☹ and ask the leading time system to send EC Payroll day-by-day totals in a separate set of wage types / pay codes. Although this is the simplest design, it makes life difficult for everyone up and down the payroll value-chain.

Would it be simpler if the RT (Results Table) in EC Payroll could have a day indicator against every wage type line item? How would we achieve it just using standard payroll configuration?

I have attempted to do just this in the next few steps.

 

Detailed Solution

Disclaimer: I have used a German employee and the German payroll schema to illustrate this in SAP’s Learning Hub Payroll demo system due to lack of Australian employees. All employees are fictional.

Figure 2 Infotype 2010 Data sent from the timesheet system

Please also note that within the above data, I have also added the wage type 2010 which is my custom Leading Hand Allowance wage type which may or may not be sent by the timesheet system. I will anyway override its amount later in this article.

  1. The first step is to get your PCR X930 or in this case D930 and its dependent PCRs customised.

As shown below, I have copied D930 into Z930 and also copy-created all the rules Z931, Z932, Z93A, Z933, Z934, Z935 and Z936 just in case, as I may need to write some custom logic later.

Figure 3 How Z930 drills down

 

As shown in the below screenshot, when the wage type is getting read as part of the P2010 internal table, this is the best time to query its date and its relative position to the start date of the pay period.

Figure 4 Use P2010-derived date

This date is then passed to a sub-rule as shown below which sets the C2 split to this relative position within the payroll period. With the number of times this has to be written and repeated, I agree it looks silly😊 however, it is better than readying a functional specification for a custom operation.

Figure 5 Set C2 split to the relative position within pay period

This is placed in subschema DT00 which is the Gross Remuneration subschema (XT00 for international). Please copy the subschema as well from the standard into the customer name range e.g. ZT00.

Figure 6 Where Z930 sits in the schema

Look at the result. In the following couple of screenshots, you can see how the input wage types line up in the output table.

Figure 7 Input P2010 Table

 

Figure 8 Output Table - OT with the C2 split

As seen in the above screenshot, this is the most significant step where you can get an indicator on the IT/OT wage types as to which day that payment is for. Since payroll usually deals with pay-period aggregates of wage types, this extra information in the form of a C2 split is real luxury to have which we have now made available to the rest of the schema going forward.

 

 

2. The second step is to have a placeholder for custom logic to do the day-by-day calculation of hours and/or rate and amount.

Figure 9 Placement of custom PCRs

It is better to write this logic after the amounts are available from Rule X015 so that you have everything you need.

 

 

3. Thirdly, within the rule Z901, I am ensuring that the logic only runs for the wage types which should form part of the daily aggregate.

As you can see below, this rule again seems a bit silly with querying on the C2 Split for each day of the payroll period (31, since it is monthly payroll). It will be much shorter if it is a weekly or fortnightly payroll and you can even identify days of the week based on the day in the payroll period (useful for public holiday and weekend shift counter calculations).

However, it is extremely effective in creating an aggregate wage type 9001 with the right C2 split and should just be a one-time activity again.

 

Figure 10 How Z901 is configured for each day

As shown below, the daily aggregates are neatly stacked day-by-day with rates, numbers and amounts. The rates are all same in this example, however, they can have different rates too calculated by dividing the aggregated amounts by aggregated hours.

Figure 11 WT 9001 created with right C2 split

4. Finally, we apply this information to calculate the amount of another wage type.

 

Figure 12 Use daily aggregate to derive another wage type

As you can see below, the “Leading Hand” payment is created at 9% of the other amounts paid on the same day.

 

 

 

Figure 13 Example of a 3rd wage type created from Daily Aggregate

 

Conclusion

It is possible with reliable standard SAP Payroll configuration to achieve finer granularity of data in EC payroll to have award interpretation logic for time-based payments with some improvisation. This method of having a split against the wage type with the day in the payroll period can also drive other applications such as:

  1. Counting no. of weekend shifts and paying premium
  2. Paying extra if overtime is on and/or follows a public holiday
  3. Variable pay rates per day based on timesheet and roster inputs

SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll 

HCM Payroll

entry.title: Calculate charges on freight order for delivery
entry.content:
Hi all,

In SAP Public Cloud TM the charge calculation on an Ocean Freight Booking is done for all stages in the transport (which includes the pre-carriage, main-carriage and on-carriage stage), unless specified differently in the stages tab. When creating a Freight Order for Delivery (for the on-carriage stage), there is no charge calculation done on this FO since the costs are already taken into account on the OFB.

My question is: How can I set the charge calculation on the Freight Order for Delivery? I want to create a zero rate or no settlement on the OFB (customer does not expect invoice) and set the transportation costs for the transport from the port to the customer on the FO for Delivery.

Right now, it is not possible to do charge calculation on the Freight Order for Delivery as the charges are already on the OFB:

Any suggestions on how to do this? 

Remember, this is in Public Cloud TM. 

Thank you in advance for your answer.

entry.title: Re: How does the Year-End Adjustment of Pro Rata VAT deal...
entry.content:
Hello @tvergeer,

Yes, the pro rata year-end adjustment is still calculated for WBS elements that were closed during the year. However, since postings are not allowed directly on closed WBS elements, the correction is booked at the general ledger (G/L) level using adjustment accounts defined in configuration, rather than against the closed WBS itself.

Let me explain you how SAP Handles Pro Rata Year-End Adjustments. At year-end, SAP requires recalculating VAT pro rata using the final coefficient determined by tax authorities. This ensures compliance with fiscal rules. Even if a WBS element is closed (status set to "CLSD"), the system still considers its transactions in the calculation of the final pro rata adjustment. Because no postings are permitted on closed WBS elements, SAP does not attempt to reopen them. Instead, adjustments are redirected to G/L accounts


Let me explain you how the correction is booked.

1.Configuration Setup:
The key user configures tax codes and adjustment G/L accounts specifically for year-end pro rata corrections. These accounts act as the target for postings when WBS elements are closed.

2. System Behavior:
The adjustment job posts correction entries directly to the G/L accounts. The postings are not tied to the WBS element but are instead aggregated at company code level.

3. Audit Trail:
The system maintains traceability by linking the adjustment posting to the original transactions, even though the WBS is closed. This ensures compliance without violating the "no postings on closed WBS" rule.

entry.title: Re: FF SAP Public cloud
entry.content:
Good day @SAPuser1996 

Thank you for your question.

First, it is not possible to create and use the Firefighter ID/Emergency Access Management in public cloud like you could in on-premise Access Control. The public cloud system provides business role-based access but does not contain the classic GRC Firefighter work center.

Second, if you want the Firefighter style emergency access process, I suggest you use Cloud Identity Access Governance with the Privileged Access Management

Finally, Firefighter was replaced with Identity Access Governance (IAG) through Privileged Access Management.

Have a look at the following references.

Preparing the Setup of Privileged Access Management Service

This Blog provides some good insights: Privileged Access Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud: A Comprehensive Guide

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Send Email with Image from MIME Repository in SAP ABAP.
entry.content:
Introduction

In many SAP projects, sending emails with proper formatting and images is a common requirement—whether it’s for birthday wishes, reminders, approvals, or dashboards. Recently, I faced a real-time scenario where I had to send an email that included an inline image stored in the SAP MIME Repository. Instead of attaching the image as a file, the business wanted it to appear directly inside the email body.

This pushed me to explore how the MIME Repository works and how to embed images using ABAP and the BCS classes. To make the explanation clear and easy to understand, I used AI-assisted content creation while writing this blog—helping me present the technical steps in a simple and readable format.

In this blog, I will walk you through the complete process of fetching an image from the MIME Repository and sending it in an HTML email using ABAP.
Example Code :

REPORT ZEMAIL_TO_SEND_IMG1.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------
* Data Declarations
*----------------------------------------------------------------------
DATA: lo_mime       TYPE REF TO cl_gbt_multirelated_service,
      lo_doc        TYPE REF TO cl_document_bcs,
      lo_bcs        TYPE REF TO cl_bcs,
      lo_sender     TYPE REF TO if_sender_bcs,
      lo_recipient  TYPE REF TO if_recipient_bcs.

DATA: lv_xstr       TYPE xstring,           "Image content in XSTRING
      lv_mime       TYPE w3conttype,        "MIME type like image/png
      lv_filename   TYPE string VALUE 'Done.png', "Image name
      lt_solix      TYPE solix_tab,         "Binary table
      lt_html       TYPE soli_tab,          "HTML body lines
      lv_len        TYPE so_obj_len.        "Length of binary content


*----------------------------------------------------------------------
* Step 1: Read Image From SAP MIME Repository
*----------------------------------------------------------------------
cl_mime_repository_api=>get_api( )->get(
  EXPORTING
    i_url       = |/SAP/PUBLIC/TEST_W/{ lv_filename }|
  IMPORTING
    e_content   = lv_xstr
    e_mime_type = lv_mime
  EXCEPTIONS
    OTHERS      = 1 ).

IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR lv_xstr IS INITIAL.
  MESSAGE |Image { lv_filename } missing in MIME Repo!| TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.


*----------------------------------------------------------------------
* Step 2: Convert XSTRING Image to SOLIX
*----------------------------------------------------------------------
lt_solix = cl_bcs_convert=>xstring_to_solix( lv_xstr ).
lv_len   = xstrlen( lv_xstr ).


*----------------------------------------------------------------------
* Step 3: Create MIME Multi-Part Object for Email
*----------------------------------------------------------------------
CREATE OBJECT lo_mime.


*----------------------------------------------------------------------
* Step 4: Add Inline Image (Content-ID Based Embedding)
*----------------------------------------------------------------------
lo_mime->add_binary_part(
  content      = lt_solix,
  content_type = lv_mime,
  length       = lv_len,
  content_id   = lv_filename ).   "Used as cid:Done.png in HTML


*----------------------------------------------------------------------
* Step 5: Build HTML Email Body
*----------------------------------------------------------------------
APPEND '<html>' TO lt_html.
APPEND '<body style="background-color:#e6f0fa; font-family:Arial; margin:0; padding:10px;">' TO lt_html.

APPEND '<div style="max-width:600px; margin:auto; background:#ffffff; padding:20px; border-radius:8px; border:1px solid #d0d7e3;">' TO lt_html.

APPEND '<div style="text-align:center; margin-bottom:15px;">' TO lt_html.
APPEND |<img src="cid:{ lv_filename }" alt="Birthday Image" style="width:80px;" />| TO lt_html.
APPEND '</div>' TO lt_html.

APPEND '<p style="font-size:12px; color:#000;">Dear <b>Mani JANGITI</b>,<br><br>' TO lt_html.
APPEND 'Wishing you a very Happy Birthday!<br><br>' TO lt_html.
APPEND 'May your day be filled with joy, laughter, and wonderful moments.<br>' TO lt_html.
APPEND 'May this new year of your life bring you happiness, success, good health, and all the blessings you deserve.<br><br>' TO lt_html.
APPEND 'Enjoy your special day to the fullest! <br><br>' TO lt_html.
APPEND '</p>' TO lt_html.

APPEND '<div style="text-align:center; margin:20px 0;">' TO lt_html.
APPEND '<a href="https://your-gift-link.com/open" style="background:#6a2ae8; color:#ffffff; padding:10px 20px; text-decoration:none; border-radius:6px; font-size:14px;">' TO lt_html.
APPEND 'Open Your Gift' TO lt_html.
APPEND '</a>' TO lt_html.
APPEND '</div>' TO lt_html.

APPEND '<p style="margin-top:15px; font-size:12px;">Warm Regards,<br> Company (IN)</p>' TO lt_html.

APPEND '</div>' TO lt_html.
APPEND '</body></html>' TO lt_html.


*----------------------------------------------------------------------
* Step 6: Attach HTML Body into MIME Object
*----------------------------------------------------------------------
lo_mime->set_main_html(
  content     = lt_html,
  filename    = 'email.htm',
  description = 'Birthday Wishes' ).


*----------------------------------------------------------------------
* Step 7: Create Email Document with Subject
*----------------------------------------------------------------------
lo_doc = cl_document_bcs=>create_from_multirelated(
            i_subject          = 'Birthday Wishes...',
            i_multirel_service = lo_mime ).


*----------------------------------------------------------------------
* Step 8: Create and Send Email Using BCS
*----------------------------------------------------------------------
lo_bcs = cl_bcs=>create_persistent( ).
lo_bcs->set_document( lo_doc ).

lo_sender = cl_sapuser_bcs=>create( sy-uname ).
lo_bcs->set_sender( lo_sender ).

lo_recipient = cl_cam_address_bcs=>create_internet_address(
                 'maniyadav2585@gmail.com' ).
lo_bcs->add_recipient( lo_recipient ).

lo_bcs->send( i_with_error_screen = abap_true ).
COMMIT WORK AND WAIT.


*----------------------------------------------------------------------
* Final Message
*----------------------------------------------------------------------
WRITE / 'Email sent successfully Check It in SOST. !'.

Output :


Explanation :

  1. In SAP emails, images help make the message look professional and easy to understand.

  2. The image is usually stored in the MIME Repository, which is SAP’s storage for logos, icons, and media files.

  3. When sending HTML emails, we convert the image to Base64 so that it appears directly inside the email body.

  4. We also add hyperlinks in the email so the user can click and open related documents or applications (like a Fiori app or a PDF).

  5. This method is often used in real-time scenarios like reports, dashboards, notifications, and approval emails.

Thanks for reading this blog! Implementing images and hyperlinks in SAP emails may look small, but it makes a huge difference in real-time business communication. I personally used AI tools to structure and refine this content, just like how we now use AI daily to speed up development and solve problems faster. In real project scenarios, features like embedded images, clickable links, and clean formatting help users quickly understand data and take action. Hope this guide helps you in your next SAP requirement!
 
ABAP Connectivity 
ABAP Development

entry.title: Seamlessly Transitioning Your Digital Learning to WalkMe Learning Arc
entry.content:
Introduction: Embracing the Future of Digital Learning

The workplace is changing faster than ever. Artificial intelligence, cloud transformation, and digital innovation are reshaping how work gets done—and creating a widening skills gap that traditional learning programs simply cannot close. Content becomes stale before it's even deployed. Training happens in isolation, disconnected from where employees work. Knowledge retention suffers because learning feels like a checkbox exercise rather than a practical necessity.

Today, we're bringing forward a solution built for this new reality with a transformative shift, transitioning SAP Enable Now to WalkMe Learning Arc, a modern, AI-native learning platform purpose-built for the dynamic workplace.

WalkMe Learning Arc represents a fundamental reimagining of how organizations deliver training and build lasting proficiency. Rather than relying on outdated, out-of-context learning experiences, it harnesses the power of artificial intelligence, contextual delivery, and behavioural intelligence to ensure employees learn exactly what they need, exactly when they need it—right where they work.

This transition isn't just about adopting new software. It's about unlocking a new infrastructure for digital adoption that solves real business challenges: closing skill gaps, accelerating time to proficiency, and building a workforce that can keep pace with change.

 

What This Transition Unlocks: New Possibilities

 

Content Authoring Built for Scale

One of the biggest challenges facing and other teams today is the sheer volume of content that needs to be created and maintained. Traditional approaches are labour-intensive and slow to adapt as systems and processes evolve.

WalkMe Learning Arc changes this through AI-first content authoring, which dramatically accelerates content production and maintenance. Instead of spending weeks building training materials, your team can now create, update, and deploy quality content in a fraction of the time. This solves two critical problems: the capacity constraint that limits how much training you can deliver, and the shelf-life problem that causes content to become outdated.

Beyond speed, WalkMe Learning Arc enables multi-modal experiences. Build once, ship in multiple formats. Whether your learners need full courses, microlearning, quizzes, or interactive guides, you can create a single piece of content and deliver it across multiple channels and media formats—including seamless simulation capture that brings your processes to life.

 

Contextual Delivery in the Flow of Work

Traditional learning management systems operate in isolation. Employees complete training in a separate portal, then return to their applications and struggle to apply what they learned. The disconnect is costly: knowledge doesn't transfer, and proficiency takes longer to achieve.

WalkMe Learning Arc extends training beyond the LMS and directly into the business applications where work happens. This is the power of contextual learning. When employees need help, they don't have to leave their workflow to search a training portal. Instead, they discover and consume learning content exactly where and when they need it—through in-app search, guided recommendations, and step-by-step support embedded directly in their applications.

This approach transforms learning from a separate activity into an integrated part of work itself.

 

Continuous Reinforcement That Sticks

The most powerful learning happens at the moment of need. WalkMe Learning Arc delivers just-in-time learning by harnessing our Digital Adoption expertise to provide training at the exact moment an employee encounters a task or challenge. This isn't guesswork—it's informed by behavioural intelligence.

By analysing how employees actually work, WalkMe Learning Arc uses behaviour-based segmentation and contextualized recommendations to reinforce knowledge precisely when it matters most. This continuous, contextual reinforcement builds lasting proficiency far more effectively than traditional training programs ever could.

 

The Transition Process: A Smooth, Guided Path

We've designed the transition from SAP Enable Now to WalkMe Learning Arc to be straightforward and low-risk. Here's what you need to know:

 

What Gets Transitioned

Your existing SAP Enable Now Digital Learning content becomes fully usable in the WalkMe environment. This means your content is hostable, playable, and editable—nothing is lost. Selected SAP Enable Now objects can be reused as new WalkMe Learning Arc microlearning objects, giving your content a new life in a modern platform.

Note: This transition applies to Digital Learning content only. Digital adoption content from SAP Companion (like guided tours and hot spots) is excluded from this process. You will retain the ability to share digital learning content with learners via an in-app menu experience with WalkMe Learning Arc.

Your Customer Success Manager will talk to you about your transition options during the Welcome Call and the transition feature will be turned on if required. This process might differ for selected customers or change in the future. More details for each phase will be available in the Help Documentation.

We will link to a KBA here shortly to make the information about the transition steps more consumable and shorten this blog post. 

 

Getting Started: Commercial Options

We offer flexible commercial transition options to fit your organization's timeline and budget:

  • In-Quarter Transition: Transition at your contract renewal date for a seamless alignment with your existing agreements.
  • Out-of-Quarter Transition: Move earlier if you're ready to unlock the benefits sooner. Please note that prerequisites apply.
  • Test & Go Live: Consider our optional four-month "Test & Go Live" contract, which provides a full productive WalkMe Learning Arc tenant during the transition period. This gives you time to validate the platform and ensure readiness before full cutover.

Connect with your SAP or WalkMe Account Team to plan the commercial transition.

 

Step Into the Future of Learning

The transition to WalkMe Learning Arc represents more than a platform change—it's a shift toward a learning infrastructure that’s already built for the future. One that closes skill gaps, delivers training in context, and builds lasting proficiency in a workforce that's constantly evolving.

Your existing content is safe, your transition path is clear, and the benefits are substantial. The future of learning at work is here. Find out more from our WalkMe Learning Arc website.

Ready to get started? Contact your Account Executive or Account Team to discuss the best transition path for your organization. We're here to guide you every step of the way.

entry.title: CALL BAPI IN CUSTOM ENTITY THROUGH RAP
entry.content:
Hi RAP Developers, Good Day

Introduction:

In many business scenarios, we need to expose BAPI-based data to SAP Fiori applications without creating database tables or CDS-based persistency. With the RESTful ABAP Programming Model (RAP), this can be achieved efficiently using Custom Entities, which allow us to call ABAP logic directly—such as BAPIs—and return the data as an OData service.

In this blog, I will walk through how to build a Custom Entity that fetches bank details by calling a BAPI, how to annotate it for UI consumption, and how to expose it seamlessly to a Fiori Elements application. This approach is useful whenever you want to reuse existing BAPIs and business logic while keeping your RAP model clean, lightweight, and high-performing.

Solution Overview:

This solution demonstrates how RAP can seamlessly integrate with classic SAP functionality by exposing BAPI output through a Custom Entity. Instead of relying on database tables or CDS views, the Custom Entity acts as a virtual data source whose data is supplied dynamically via an ABAP class.

When a Fiori Elements UI requests the entity, RAP forwards the query to the ABAP implementation class. This class reads the query parameters (filters, sorting, pagination) and uses them to call BAPI_BANK_GETDETAIL. The BAPI returns the bank’s address, master data, and related details, which are then transformed into the response structure expected by the Custom Entity.

The result is an OData-based, read-only endpoint capable of delivering real-time data from a BAPI with full RAP features such as filtering, sorting, paging, and total count support. This approach makes it easy to modernize existing SAP data retrieval logic while still leveraging stable, proven BAPIs in the backend.


Custom Entity:

  • custom entity not underlying any data source.
  • data preview is not possible, becuase this should be implemented in seperate class.
  • suitable for paging,calling bapi's and external api's.
@EndUserText.label: 'Custom Entity calling bapi'
@ObjectModel: {
    query: {
        implementedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_BAPI_BANK'
    }
}

@UI: {
    headerInfo: {
        typeName: 'Banks',
        typeNamePlural: 'Banks',
        title: { value: 'bank_ctry' },
        description: { value: 'bank_ctry' }
    }
}

@UI: {
    presentationVariant: [{
        sortOrder: [{
            by: 'bank_ctry',
            direction: #ASC
        }],
        visualizations: [{
            type: #AS_LINEITEM
        }]
    }]
}
define root custom entity ZCE_BANK
{
      .facet                : [
      {
          id      : 'Bank_data',
          purpose : #STANDARD,
          type    : #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE,
          label   : 'Bank Details',
          position: 10 }
      ]
      .lineItem             : [{ position: 10 }]
      .selectionField       : [{position: 10}]
      .identification       : [{position: 10}]
  key bank_ctry                : banks;
      .lineItem             : [{ position: 20 }]
      .selectionField       : [{position: 20}]
      .identification       : [{position: 20}]
  key bank_key                 : bankk;

      .lineItem             : [{ position: 30 }]
      .identification       : [{position: 30}]
      bank_name                : banka;

      .lineItem             : [{ position: 40 }]
      .identification       : [{position: 40}]
      street                   : stras_gp;

      .lineItem             : [{ position: 50 }]
      .identification       : [{position: 50}]
      city                     : ort01_gp;

      .lineItem             : [{ position: 60 }]
      .identification       : [{position: 60}]
      BANK_NO                  : bankl;

      .lineItem             : [{ position: 70 }]
      .identification       : [{position: 70}]
      CREAT_DATE               : erdat_bf;

      .lineItem             : [{ position: 80 }]
      .identification       : [{position: 80}]
      creator                  : ernam_bf;
}


Implementation:

CLASS ZCL_BAPI_BANK DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC .

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    " RAP interface for query implementation
    INTERFACES IF_RAP_QUERY_PROVIDER.
  PROTECTED SECTION.
  PRIVATE SECTION.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS ZCL_BAPI_BANK IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD IF_RAP_QUERY_PROVIDER~SELECT.

    "----------------------------------------------------------------------
    " Local type used to return data back to Custom Entity ZCE_BANK
    "----------------------------------------------------------------------
    TYPES: BEGIN OF TY_BANK_RESULT,
             BANK_CTRY  TYPE BANKS,
             BANK_KEY   TYPE BANKK,
             BANK_NAME  TYPE BANKA,
             STREET     TYPE STRAS_GP,
             CITY       TYPE ORT01_GP,
             BANK_NO    TYPE BANKL,
             CREAT_DATE TYPE ERDAT_BF,
             CREATOR    TYPE ERNAM_BF,
           END OF TY_BANK_RESULT.

    DATA: LT_RESULT  TYPE TABLE OF TY_BANK_RESULT,
          LS_RESULT  TYPE TY_BANK_RESULT,
          LS_ADDRESS TYPE BAPI1011_ADDRESS,
          LS_DETAIL  TYPE BAPI1011_DETAIL,
          LS_RETURN  TYPE BAPIRET2.

    " Proceed only if the consumer has requested data
    IF IO_REQUEST->IS_DATA_REQUESTED( ).

      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      " Read pagination details (TOP and SKIP)
      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      DATA(LV_TOP)  = IO_REQUEST->GET_PAGING( )->GET_PAGE_SIZE( ).
      DATA(LV_SKIP) = IO_REQUEST->GET_PAGING( )->GET_OFFSET( ).

      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      " Prepare ORDER BY clause based on sort request from UI
      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      DATA(LT_SORT) = IO_REQUEST->GET_SORT_ELEMENTS( ).
      DATA LV_ORDERBY TYPE STRING.

      IF LT_SORT IS NOT INITIAL.
        CLEAR LV_ORDERBY.

        LOOP AT LT_SORT INTO DATA(LS_SORT).
          IF SY-TABIX > 1.
            LV_ORDERBY = |{ LV_ORDERBY }, |.
          ENDIF.

          " Construct ORDER BY element (ASCENDING/DESCENDING)
          LV_ORDERBY =
            |{ LV_ORDERBY }{ LS_SORT-ELEMENT_NAME } {
               COND #( WHEN LS_SORT-DESCENDING = ABAP_TRUE
                       THEN 'DESCENDING'
                       ELSE 'ASCENDING' ) }|.
        ENDLOOP.
      ENDIF.

      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      " Derive SQL filter string from UI filter (if any)
      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      DATA(lv_conditions) = io_request->get_filter( )->get_as_sql_string( ).

      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      " Read bank master records (BNKA) based on filters
      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      SELECT BANKS AS bank_ctry,
             BANKL AS bank_key,
             BNKLZ AS bank_no,
             ERDAT AS creat_date,
             ERNAM AS creator
        FROM BNKA
        WHERE (lv_conditions)
        ORDER BY (lv_orderby)
        INTO TABLE @DATA(lt_banks)
        UP TO @LV_top ROWS
        OFFSET @LV_skip.

      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      " Loop through each BNKA record and enrich details using BAPI
      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      LOOP AT lt_banks INTO DATA(ls_bank).

        " Get detailed bank address info
        CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_BANK_GETDETAIL'
          EXPORTING
            bankcountry  = ls_bank-bank_ctry
            bankkey      = ls_bank-bank_key
          IMPORTING
            bank_address = ls_address
            bank_detail  = ls_detail
            return       = ls_return.

        " Prepare output row
        LS_RESULT-bank_ctry   = ls_bank-bank_ctry.
        LS_RESULT-bank_key    = ls_bank-bank_key.
        LS_RESULT-bank_name   = ls_address-bank_name.
        LS_RESULT-street      = ls_address-street.
        LS_RESULT-city        = ls_address-city.
        LS_RESULT-bank_no     = ls_bank-bank_no.
        LS_RESULT-creat_date  = ls_bank-creat_date.
        LS_RESULT-creator     = ls_bank-creator.

        APPEND LS_RESULT TO LT_RESULT.

        CLEAR: ls_result, ls_address, ls_detail, ls_return.

      ENDLOOP.

      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      " Return total count for UI pagination (if requested)
      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      IF IO_REQUEST->IS_TOTAL_NUMB_OF_REC_REQUESTED( ).
        SELECT COUNT(*)
          FROM BNKA
          WHERE (lv_conditions)
          INTO @DATA(lv_count).

        IO_RESPONSE->SET_TOTAL_NUMBER_OF_RECORDS( lv_count ).
      ENDIF.

      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      " Send final result back to RAP framework
      "---------------------------------------------------------------
      IO_RESPONSE->SET_DATA( LT_RESULT ).

    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

Conclusion: 
this approach highlights how RAP can modernize SAP applications by exposing classic BAPI data through Custom Entities. It enables real-time, read-only access with full OData capabilities—filtering, sorting, paging—without changing existing backend logic, bridging the gap between proven SAP functionality and modern Fiori UIs.
Thanks For Reading, Best Wishes

entry.title: Introducing SAP Continuous Influence for SAP Advanced Financial Closing
entry.content:
Dear finance experts,

We’ve got some exciting news! SAP Continuous Influence now has its very own dedicated session for SAP Advanced Financial Closing. This means a much clearer and easier way for you to check out ideas and vote on them, separate from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Finance session. 

Think of this as your direct line to SAP Product Management. You can submit your own improvement ideas, see what others are suggesting, and even vote or add your comments. Your votes are crucial because they help us prioritize what gets reviewed and potentially added to the backlog. The voting threshold is 8 votes. When voting, please consider which solutions you would like to use productively once available. We’ll keep you updated on the review outcomes in a blog post right within the SAP Advanced Financial Closing session.

When submitting your request, you can choose from the following categories:

  • Task List Creation
  • Task Processing
  • Reporting
  • Configuration and Administration
  • Cross Topics
  • Other

Ready to share your ideas? Go to the session now and start following it to receive updates. If you’re new to Continuous Influence, there’s a helpful Getting Started guide that covers everything from registering to getting notifications. 

Your ideas and suggestions are incredibly valuable for shaping the future of SAP Advanced Financial Closing. We’re looking forward to enhancing the product together with you! 

Your AFC Product Team

 

For more information on SAP Advanced Financial Closing, check out the following links:

    • SAP Community Page
    • SAP Help Portal
    • SAP Roadmap Explorer
    • SAP.com Page

entry.title: Date Hierarchy Using Tree ALV(FM & OOPS )
entry.content:
Hi Everyone

Introduction:

The user needs an interactive Date Hierarchy display in SAP that provides a structured view of years, months, and individual dates.This helps users quickly navigate through large date ranges and select specific dates for downstream operations such as data extraction, reporting, or analysis.

Solution Overview:

 

  • The screen should display a hierarchical Tree ALV titled “DATE HIERARCHY”.

  • The top-level nodes represent Years (e.g., 2021 to 2025).

  • When the user expands a Year, the 12 months (January to December) are displayed as child nodes.

  • When the user expands a Month, all valid calendar dates for that month are dynamically generated and displayed.

  • Each date node should display the date in user’s local format (DD.MM.YYYY).

  • The user should be able to:

    • Expand/collapse nodes dynamically.

    • View all levels of hierarchy.

 

TABLES : BKPF.

"Internal table and work area for tree nodes
DATA: IT_NODE TYPE TABLE OF SNODETEXT,
      WA_NODE TYPE SNODETEXT.

"Variables for Year, Month, Date calculations
DATA: LV_YEAR  TYPE GJAHR,
      LV_MONTH TYPE NUMC2,
      LV_DATE  TYPE DATUM,
      LV_DAYS  TYPE I,
      LV_DAY   TYPE NUMC2.

"Keys for hierarchy levels
DATA: LV_YEAR_KEY  TYPE CHAR10,
      LV_MONTH_KEY TYPE CHAR15,
      LV_DATE_KEY  TYPE CHAR20.

"Selection range for fiscal year
SELECT-OPTIONS: S_GJAHR FOR BKPF-GJAHR DEFAULT '2021' TO '2025'.

START-OF-SELECTION.

  CLEAR: WA_NODE, IT_NODE.

"------------------------------------------------------------"
" Root Node Creation                                         "
"------------------------------------------------------------"
WA_NODE-TYPE    = 'T'.             "Tree title
WA_NODE-NAME    = 'DATE HIERARCHY'.
WA_NODE-TLEVEL  = '01'.
WA_NODE-NLENGTH = '18'.
WA_NODE-COLOR   = '05'.
APPEND WA_NODE TO IT_NODE.
CLEAR WA_NODE.

"------------------------------------------------------------"
" Build Year → Month → Date Hierarchy                       "
"------------------------------------------------------------"
LOOP AT S_GJAHR.
  DO.
    "Loop through each year within the selected range
    LV_YEAR = S_GJAHR-LOW + SY-INDEX - 1.
    IF LV_YEAR > S_GJAHR-HIGH.
      EXIT.
    ENDIF.

    "--------------------------------------------------------"
    " Year Node (Level 02)                                   "
    "--------------------------------------------------------"
    LV_YEAR_KEY = LV_YEAR.
    WA_NODE-TYPE    = 'P'.
    WA_NODE-ID      = LV_YEAR_KEY.
    CONCATENATE LV_YEAR ' ' INTO WA_NODE-NAME SEPARATED BY SPACE.
    WA_NODE-TLEVEL  = '02'.
    WA_NODE-NLENGTH = STRLEN( WA_NODE-NAME ).
    WA_NODE-COLOR   = '03'.
    APPEND WA_NODE TO IT_NODE.
    CLEAR WA_NODE.

    "--------------------------------------------------------"
    " 12 Months Loop (Level 03)                              "
    "--------------------------------------------------------"
    DO 12 TIMES.
      LV_MONTH = SY-INDEX.
      CONCATENATE LV_YEAR_KEY LV_MONTH INTO LV_MONTH_KEY.

      WA_NODE-TYPE = 'P'.
      WA_NODE-ID   = LV_MONTH_KEY.

      "Month Name Assignment"
      CASE LV_MONTH.
        WHEN '01'. WA_NODE-NAME = 'January'.
        WHEN '02'. WA_NODE-NAME = 'February'.
        WHEN '03'. WA_NODE-NAME = 'March'.
        WHEN '04'. WA_NODE-NAME = 'April'.
        WHEN '05'. WA_NODE-NAME = 'May'.
        WHEN '06'. WA_NODE-NAME = 'June'.
        WHEN '07'. WA_NODE-NAME = 'July'.
        WHEN '08'. WA_NODE-NAME = 'August'.
        WHEN '09'. WA_NODE-NAME = 'September'.
        WHEN '10'. WA_NODE-NAME = 'October'.
        WHEN '11'. WA_NODE-NAME = 'November'.
        WHEN '12'. WA_NODE-NAME = 'December'.
      ENDCASE.

      WA_NODE-TLEVEL  = '03'.
      WA_NODE-NLENGTH = STRLEN( WA_NODE-NAME ).
      WA_NODE-COLOR   = '04'.
      APPEND WA_NODE TO IT_NODE.
      CLEAR WA_NODE.

      "------------------------------------------------------"
      " Determine number of days in the month                "
      "------------------------------------------------------"
      CONCATENATE LV_YEAR LV_MONTH '01' INTO LV_DATE.
      CALL FUNCTION 'SLS_MISC_GET_LAST_DAY_OF_MONTH'
        EXPORTING
          DAY_IN            = LV_DATE
        IMPORTING
          LAST_DAY_OF_MONTH = LV_DATE.

      LV_DAYS = LV_DATE+6(2). "Extract day part → last day of month

      "------------------------------------------------------"
      " Date Nodes (Level 04)                                "
      "------------------------------------------------------"
      DO LV_DAYS TIMES.
        LV_DAY = SY-INDEX.
        CONCATENATE LV_YEAR LV_MONTH LV_DAY INTO LV_DATE_KEY.

        WA_NODE-TYPE    = 'P'.
        WA_NODE-ID      = LV_DATE_KEY.
        CONCATENATE LV_DAY '.' LV_MONTH '.' LV_YEAR INTO WA_NODE-NAME.
        WA_NODE-TLEVEL  = '04'.
        WA_NODE-NLENGTH = STRLEN( WA_NODE-NAME ).
        WA_NODE-COLOR   = '06'.
        APPEND WA_NODE TO IT_NODE.
        CLEAR WA_NODE.

      ENDDO.

    ENDDO.

  ENDDO.
ENDLOOP.

"------------------------------------------------------------"
" Display the Tree Output                                    "
"------------------------------------------------------------"
CALL FUNCTION 'RS_TREE_CONSTRUCT'
  TABLES
    NODETAB = IT_NODE.

CALL FUNCTION 'RS_TREE_LIST_DISPLAY'
  EXPORTING
    CALLBACK_PROGRAM = SY-REPID.

Output:

OOPS Approach:

TABLES: MARA, BKPF.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Data Declarations
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
"ALV Tree objects
DATA: GO_TREE      TYPE REF TO CL_GUI_ALV_TREE,
      GO_CONTAINER TYPE REF TO CL_GUI_CUSTOM_CONTAINER.

"ALV field catalog and layout
DATA: GT_FIELDCAT TYPE LVC_T_FCAT,
      GS_FIELDCAT TYPE LVC_S_FCAT,
      GS_LAYOUT   TYPE LVC_S_LAYO.

"Output structure for tree text
TYPES: BEGIN OF TY_OUTPUT,
         COLUMN1 TYPE CHAR255,  "Single text column for tree nodes
       END OF TY_OUTPUT.

DATA: GT_OUTPUT TYPE TABLE OF TY_OUTPUT,
      GS_OUTPUT TYPE TY_OUTPUT.

"Variables used for Year → Month → Date hierarchy
DATA: LV_YEAR       TYPE GJAHR,
      LV_MONTH      TYPE NUMC2,
      LV_DATE       TYPE DATUM,
      LV_LAST_DATE  TYPE DATUM,
      LV_DAYS       TYPE I,
      LV_DAY        TYPE NUMC2,
      LV_YEAR_KEY   TYPE LVC_NKEY,
      LV_MONTH_KEY  TYPE LVC_NKEY,
      LV_DATES_LINE TYPE STRING.

"Node layout (folder / item)
DATA: LS_NODE_LAYOUT TYPE LVC_S_LAYN.

"Year range for hierarchy
SELECT-OPTIONS: S_GJAHR FOR BKPF-GJAHR DEFAULT '2021' TO '2025'.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Selection Screen Trigger
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
START-OF-SELECTION.
  CALL SCREEN 100.  "Call main screen

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* PBO: Set status and create tree
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
MODULE STATUS_0100 OUTPUT.
  SET PF-STATUS 'ZSTANDARD'.

  "Create the tree only once
  IF GO_CONTAINER IS INITIAL.
    PERFORM CREATE_AND_FILL_TREE.
  ENDIF.
ENDMODULE.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* PAI: Handle user commands
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
MODULE USER_COMMAND_0100 INPUT.
  CASE SY-UCOMM.
    WHEN 'BACK' OR 'EXIT' OR 'CANCEL'.
      "Release frontend controls
      PERFORM FREE_RESOURCES.
      LEAVE TO SCREEN 0.
  ENDCASE.
ENDMODULE.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Create container, tree control, root node and load hierarchy
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM CREATE_AND_FILL_TREE.

  "Create custom container inside screen element 'CONTAINER'
  CREATE OBJECT GO_CONTAINER
    EXPORTING
      CONTAINER_NAME = 'CONTAINER'.

  "Build ALV field catalog
  PERFORM BUILD_FIELDCAT.

  "Create ALV tree control
  CREATE OBJECT GO_TREE
    EXPORTING
      PARENT              = GO_CONTAINER
      NODE_SELECTION_MODE = CL_GUI_COLUMN_TREE=>NODE_SEL_MODE_SINGLE
      ITEM_SELECTION      = 'X'
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS              = 1.

  "Bind output table and field catalog to tree
  CALL METHOD GO_TREE->SET_TABLE_FOR_FIRST_DISPLAY
    CHANGING
      IT_OUTTAB       = GT_OUTPUT
      IT_FIELDCATALOG = GT_FIELDCAT.

  "---------------------------------------------------------------*
  " Create Root Node (DATE HIERARCHY)
  "---------------------------------------------------------------*
  CLEAR: LS_NODE_LAYOUT, GS_OUTPUT.
  LS_NODE_LAYOUT-ISFOLDER  = 'X'.
  LS_NODE_LAYOUT-N_IMAGE   = '@AV@'.
  LS_NODE_LAYOUT-EXP_IMAGE = '@AV@'.
  GS_OUTPUT-COLUMN1        = 'DATE HIERARCHY'.

  "Add root node
  CALL METHOD GO_TREE->ADD_NODE
    EXPORTING
      I_RELAT_NODE_KEY = ''  "Root level
      I_RELATIONSHIP   = CL_GUI_COLUMN_TREE=>RELAT_LAST_CHILD
      IS_OUTTAB_LINE   = GS_OUTPUT
      IS_NODE_LAYOUT   = LS_NODE_LAYOUT
    IMPORTING
      E_NEW_NODE_KEY   = LV_YEAR_KEY.

  "Build full tree under root node
  PERFORM BUILD_TREE_NODES USING LV_YEAR_KEY.

  "Auto-expand root node
  CALL METHOD GO_TREE->EXPAND_NODE
    EXPORTING
      I_NODE_KEY = LV_YEAR_KEY.

  CALL METHOD GO_TREE->FRONTEND_UPDATE.

ENDFORM.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Create field catalog for ALV tree
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM BUILD_FIELDCAT.
  CLEAR GS_FIELDCAT.
  GS_FIELDCAT-FIELDNAME = 'COLUMN1'.
  GS_FIELDCAT-COLTEXT   = 'Description'.
  GS_FIELDCAT-OUTPUTLEN = 255.
  APPEND GS_FIELDCAT TO GT_FIELDCAT.
ENDFORM.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Build YEAR → MONTH → DAY hierarchy inside ALV Tree
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM BUILD_TREE_NODES USING IV_ROOT_KEY TYPE LVC_NKEY.

  DATA: LV_PARENT_YEAR  TYPE LVC_NKEY,
        LV_PARENT_MONTH TYPE LVC_NKEY,
        LV_MONTH_NAME   TYPE STRING,
        LV_CHUNK        TYPE STRING,
        LV_CHUNK_COUNT  TYPE I,
        GV_GROUP_SIZE   TYPE I VALUE 10,  "Group 10 days per line
        LV_DATE_STRING  TYPE STRING.

  "Loop through selected year range
  LOOP AT S_GJAHR.
    DO.
      LV_YEAR = S_GJAHR-LOW + SY-INDEX - 1.
      IF LV_YEAR > S_GJAHR-HIGH.
        EXIT.
      ENDIF.

      "---------------------------------------------------------------*
      " Create YEAR Node
      "---------------------------------------------------------------*
      CLEAR: LS_NODE_LAYOUT, GS_OUTPUT.
      LS_NODE_LAYOUT-ISFOLDER  = 'X'.
      LS_NODE_LAYOUT-N_IMAGE   = '@AV@'.
      LS_NODE_LAYOUT-EXP_IMAGE = '@AV@'.
      GS_OUTPUT-COLUMN1        = |Year: { LV_YEAR }|.

      CALL METHOD GO_TREE->ADD_NODE
        EXPORTING
          I_RELAT_NODE_KEY = IV_ROOT_KEY      "Attach to root
          I_RELATIONSHIP   = CL_GUI_COLUMN_TREE=>RELAT_LAST_CHILD
          IS_OUTTAB_LINE   = GS_OUTPUT
          IS_NODE_LAYOUT   = LS_NODE_LAYOUT
        IMPORTING
          E_NEW_NODE_KEY   = LV_PARENT_YEAR.

      "---------------------------------------------------------------*
      " Create MONTH Nodes under each Year
      "---------------------------------------------------------------*
      DO 12 TIMES.
        LV_MONTH = SY-INDEX.

        "Month name mapping
        CASE LV_MONTH.
          WHEN 1.  LV_MONTH_NAME = 'January'.
          WHEN 2.  LV_MONTH_NAME = 'February'.
          WHEN 3.  LV_MONTH_NAME = 'March'.
          WHEN 4.  LV_MONTH_NAME = 'April'.
          WHEN 5.  LV_MONTH_NAME = 'May'.
          WHEN 6.  LV_MONTH_NAME = 'June'.
          WHEN 7.  LV_MONTH_NAME = 'July'.
          WHEN 8.  LV_MONTH_NAME = 'August'.
          WHEN 9.  LV_MONTH_NAME = 'September'.
          WHEN 10. LV_MONTH_NAME = 'October'.
          WHEN 11. LV_MONTH_NAME = 'November'.
          WHEN 12. LV_MONTH_NAME = 'December'.
        ENDCASE.

        CLEAR: LS_NODE_LAYOUT, GS_OUTPUT.
        LS_NODE_LAYOUT-ISFOLDER  = 'X'.
        LS_NODE_LAYOUT-N_IMAGE   = '@2L@'.
        LS_NODE_LAYOUT-EXP_IMAGE = '@2L@'.
        GS_OUTPUT-COLUMN1        = LV_MONTH_NAME.

        "Add Month node
        CALL METHOD GO_TREE->ADD_NODE
          EXPORTING
            I_RELAT_NODE_KEY = LV_PARENT_YEAR
            I_RELATIONSHIP   = CL_GUI_COLUMN_TREE=>RELAT_LAST_CHILD
            IS_OUTTAB_LINE   = GS_OUTPUT
            IS_NODE_LAYOUT   = LS_NODE_LAYOUT
          IMPORTING
            E_NEW_NODE_KEY   = LV_PARENT_MONTH.

        "-----------------------------------------------------------*
        " Determine last day of month
        "-----------------------------------------------------------*
        CONCATENATE LV_YEAR LV_MONTH '01' INTO LV_DATE.
        CALL FUNCTION 'LAST_DAY_OF_MONTHS'
          EXPORTING
            DAY_IN            = LV_DATE
          IMPORTING
            LAST_DAY_OF_MONTH = LV_LAST_DATE.

        LV_DAYS = LV_LAST_DATE+6(2).  "Extract number of days

        "-----------------------------------------------------------*
        " Add DAY Nodes grouped (10 days per node)
        "-----------------------------------------------------------*
        CLEAR: LV_CHUNK, LV_CHUNK_COUNT.

        DO LV_DAYS TIMES.
          LV_DAY = SY-INDEX.

          "Format date string: DD.MM.YYYY
          LV_DATE_STRING = |{ LV_DAY WIDTH = 2 }.{ LV_MONTH WIDTH = 2 }.{ LV_YEAR }|.

          "Build chunk of 10 dates
          IF LV_CHUNK IS INITIAL.
            LV_CHUNK = LV_DATE_STRING.
          ELSE.
            CONCATENATE LV_CHUNK LV_DATE_STRING INTO LV_CHUNK SEPARATED BY SPACE.
          ENDIF.

          ADD 1 TO LV_CHUNK_COUNT.

          "Add one group node after every 10 days OR last day
          IF LV_CHUNK_COUNT >= GV_GROUP_SIZE OR LV_DAY = LV_DAYS.

            CLEAR: LS_NODE_LAYOUT, GS_OUTPUT.
            LS_NODE_LAYOUT-ISFOLDER = ''.   "Leaf node
            LS_NODE_LAYOUT-N_IMAGE  = '@3C@'.
            GS_OUTPUT-COLUMN1       = LV_CHUNK.

            "Add day-chunk node
            CALL METHOD GO_TREE->ADD_NODE
              EXPORTING
                I_RELAT_NODE_KEY = LV_PARENT_MONTH
                I_RELATIONSHIP   = CL_GUI_COLUMN_TREE=>RELAT_LAST_CHILD
                IS_OUTTAB_LINE   = GS_OUTPUT
                IS_NODE_LAYOUT   = LS_NODE_LAYOUT.

            CLEAR: LV_CHUNK, LV_CHUNK_COUNT.
          ENDIF.
        ENDDO.

      ENDDO.  "End Month Loop

    ENDDO.
  ENDLOOP.

ENDFORM.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Release frontend controls
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM FREE_RESOURCES.
  IF GO_TREE IS BOUND.
    CALL METHOD GO_TREE->FREE.
    FREE GO_TREE.
  ENDIF.

  IF GO_CONTAINER IS BOUND.
    CALL METHOD GO_CONTAINER->FREE.
    FREE GO_CONTAINER.
  ENDIF.
ENDFORM.

 Conclusion:
This solution showcases a practical and user-friendly way to visualize date structures by building a dynamic Year–Month–Day hierarchy using the ALV Tree control. By grouping daily entries and leveraging container-based GUI elements, the approach delivers a clean, scalable, and intuitive navigation experience. It also demonstrates how classic ABAP techniques—selection screens, tree controls, and month/day calculations—can be combined to create interactive UI components that enhance data exploration within SAP GUI.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Activate Distribution Model For Cost Center...
entry.content:
To resolve the activation issue with the Push Distribution Model for Cost Center, follow these steps:

  1. Clean Up MDI Bookkeeping Tables: Ensure that the MDI bookkeeping tables are cleared. This step is crucial for the activation process.

  2. Delete Entries in Relevant Tables: In addition to cleaning the bookkeeping tables, delete entries in the database table CSKS_MAP along with the MDI_BO_INSTANCE table.

  3. Activate Push Model: After performing the above steps, attempt to activate your Push Distribution Model again.

  4. Replication: Once activated, replicate the data to MDI. Confirmations should be pulled from MDI within 5 minutes, and the replication status should adjust accordingly.

This approach has been successful in resolving similar issues. Please try these steps and let us know if it works for you.
