entry.title: Microsoft GRAPH API - Read and extract attachments of Outlook email from Cloud Integration
entry.content:
This blog is to help when there is no IMAP or POP allowed with Outlook email to use Sender Mail adapter; we have an alternative approach with GRAPH API.

Prerequisites to connect Microsoft 365 Outlook to Cloud Integration:

  1. User should have “Application Administrator” and “Application developer” role in Microsoft Azure.

  2. Register a new application using the Azure portal.

  3. Create client credentials.

  4. Set API permissions and grant admin consent.

  5. Determine Redirect url.

  6. Make a request to Azure Active Directory authentication service using HTTP POST with a client ID and client secret to retrieve an access token.

  7. Use the access token to make HTTP requests to Microsoft Graph REST API.

Refer below Blog for the Configuration:

https://community.sap.com/t5/integration-blog-posts/cloud-integration-connect-to-microsoft-365-mail-with-oauth2/ba-p/13465693

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/cloud-integration-call-microsoft-graph-api-with-oauth-2-0-authorization/ba-p/13487188

Cloud Integration Steps:

Step 1: Create OAuth2 Client Credentials to connect with Microsoft 365 Outlook

Go to Monitor – Manage Security - click on Create and choose “OAuth2 Client Credentials”



Provide a meaningful name for the credential “Name”

Select “Grant Type”, “Client Authentication”, “Content Type” from the drop down available in the configuration based on the requirement.

Enter the “Token Service URL”, “Client ID”, “Client Secret” and “Scope” from Microsoft app and click on deploy.

Now your credential is ready to be used in HTTP Receiver Adapter configuration in the IFlow.

Step 2: Create a Artifact/ IFlow

Go to Design- Integrations and APIs – create a Package – create an Artifact – Click on Add button and create an Integration Flow.

Start with Start Timer for the scheduler and create a Content Modifier to set up Content Type and Grant type.

Step 3: Connect with HTTP Receiver Adapter to call Microsoft Graph API

Enter REST API url in the address to read Outlook email

Select Method GET to extract the Inbox email.

Authentication: Select OAuth2 Client Credentials

Credential Name : Enter the name which was created in the Security Material.

Save and deploy. Now we can see the connectivity between Microsoft 365 Outlook and CPI is successful and able to extract data.

Convert this payload from JSON to xml.

Step 4: To get the attachment details from the read email.

Create a content modifier and set up a property to store "MessageID" which was received in the previous output data.

Create a request reply and connect to HTTP receiver adapter and call the "MessageID" in the url to get the attachment details.

Convert this payload from JSON to xml.

Step 5: To get the PDF attachment from the email.

Create a Content modifier to store a “id” value which was received from previous step.

Connect with HTTP receiver adapter again and call the exchange property “MessageID & ValueID” in the address url query to get attachment.

Scenario 1: After "Step 5" once you deploy the IFlow,  we will get the attachment of email and that can be placed in SFTP Folder with the same format.

Scenario 2: If you wanted to extract the content from the PDF attachment - After "Step 5", create a Groovy with below groovy script.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import java.util.HashMap;
// package org.apache.pdfbox.examples.util;
import org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.PDDocument
import org.apache.pdfbox.util.PDFTextStripper

public static String readFromPDF(InputStream input){
        PDDocument pd;
        try {
            pd = PDDocument.load(input);
            PDFTextStripper stripper = new PDFTextStripper();
            stripper.setStartPage(1); // Start Page
//          stripper.setEndPage(1); // End Page
            String text = stripper.getText(pd);
            if (pd != null) {
                pd.close();
            }
            return text.toString()
        } catch (Exception e){
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
        return null
    }

def Message processData(Message message) {
        def body = message.getBody();
        InputStream IS = body;
        String res = readFromPDF(IS)

    message.setBody(res);
    return message;
}

After creating a Groovy script, download the "pdfbox" and "fontbox" from the below link and upload the JAR file in the Reference tab of your iFlow.

  • Download the pdfbox JAR file from the following link.
  • Download the fontbox JAR file from the following link.

Scenario 3: If you wanted to get whole email content along with attachment.

After "Step 3" - Create a content modifier and set up a property to store "MessageID" value.

Create a request reply and connect to HTTP receiver adapter by calling the exchange property "MessageID" in the url along with “$value”.

If you wanted to encode the received data from the above query, use "BASE64 Encode" to send encoded payload to respective receiver system.

Note: Outlook mail connector is also possible through Open connector.

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-cloud-platform-connect-to-outlook-mail-using-open-connectors/ba-p/13368683

entry.title: Staging / Picking materials from different EWM sloc
entry.content:
Business use Decentralize EWM and have two EWM sloc (0001 main wh, 0002 production wh).
So now we have stock in both 0001, 0002.
Now I need a the Production material request to pick the material either from 0001 or from 0002. How to set the master data for this.
In control cycle for ewm staging its not possible to maintain the different destination and source storage location.


Is there any control we can do in /n/SCWM/PSASTAGE to stage material either from 0001 main warehouse or 0002 production warehouse.

entry.title: Calibration end date vs Form end date
entry.content:
Hello,

We have found out a conflict between end dates in Calibration and Performance Management.

- Calibration end date = date 00h00min e.g. 31st Dec 2025 00h00m

- Form end date = date 23h59 min e.g. 31 st Dec 2025 23h59

This causes issues in People Profile because the sorting order is based on the rating end date : 2635378 - Sorting Order of Background and Trend Data in Employee Profile - SAP for Me

So the common belief that PM form dates and Calibration dates should match is incorrect because of the design.

To have the correct order in People Profile you have to set the dates as follows:

- Form end date = 31 st Dec 2025 23h59

- Calibration end date = 1st Jan 2026 00h00

Could SAP SuccessFactors team advise on when they are going to make end dates and times match?

Kind Regards,

Abdelrani

entry.title: Re: Validation Rules
entry.content:
@sotirisgiog 

In SAC validation rules are more driven from Master Data and not fact Data. Generally its based on attributes or hard coded member values. 

You cannot define validation rules based on fact data but what you can do is re classify the input data into right combination using past historical fact records using a Data Action. 

Please note this will not prevent any wrong combination input but only re process the data into right combination post the Data Action run.

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: Why do parked invoices (e.g doc. type, RE, DR) not di...
entry.content:
Dear @Eduard5,

Question 1.

In Public Cloud a parked supplier invoice (document type RE) is not treated like a parked FI journal entry. For RE, SAP parks the MM supplier-invoice document (Invoice Verification object) and does not create the FI expense/G/L line items yet. Because those FI G/L line items don’t exist, they also can’t be stored in / exposed by the FI parked-document structures (VBKPF/VBSEG*) and therefore don’t show up in Manage Journal Entries or in the released I_ParkedOplAcctgDoc* CDS views.

SAP explicitly describes this as standard behavior and contrasts it with parked G/L journal entries where a full parked FI document is created immediately so yes what you’re seeing is effectively a light accounting representation on the FI side for parked RE invoices until posting, there are no FI expense postings to report (no debit lines, no CO assignments) only the supplier-invoice document data exists on the logistics/AP invoice object side

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3685396

Question 2.

Is there any CDS view that exposes cost objects for parked RE invoices before posting? Not via FI parked-document CDS views because the FI G/L items do not exist yet BUT you can get the cost objects from the Supplier Invoice (MM) API / CDS layer, which is where the parked invoice coding is actually stored

Use the released supplier-invoice interface CDS views such as:

  • I_SupplierInvoiceAPI01
  • I_SuplrInvoiceItemGLAcctAPI01

Those are the right data sources for parked RE invoice cost assignment before posting

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3273168

https://api.sap.com/cdsviews/I_SUPLRINVOICEITEMGLACCTAPI01

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: How to write Table function in stranded way like SAP
entry.content:
How to Write CDS Table Functions the Standard SAP Way

In SAP S/4HANA, we cannot always express complex business logic using pure CDS syntax. To manage scenarios like long text processing, procedural calculations, or important joins, SAP uses CDS Table Functions implemented through AMDP.

While many developers create table functions on the fly, SAP sticks to a strict and consistent design pattern across its standard content. This approach ensures good performance, readability, upgrade safety, and transportability.

A useful way to grasp this standard is to look at how SAP builds transactional CDS views, especially those that use CDS Table Functions. By examining SAP-delivered objects like I_SalesOrderTP, we can clearly see the structure, naming conventions, annotations, and implementation method that SAP expects developers to follow.

This guide explains how SAP writes table functions, how they implement them using AMDP, and how they use them in CDS views. This will help you design your own extensions in the same way SAP does.

  1. Start with a Standard View: I_SALESORDERTP.
  • SAP provides many standard CDS views in S/4HANA.
  • To understand how SAP writes table functions, the easiest example is the view: I_SALESORDERTP
  • This is a Transactional Processing View, delivered by SAP.

   2. Locate the Table Function Used Inside the View.

  • Inside the view, you will notice SAP has used: with parameters (...).

  • This indicates that the view is consuming a CDS Table Function.

        3. You will find the CDS Table Function that SAP has written.

    4.  Open the AMDP Class to See SAP’s Logic.

  • Once you find the Table Function name, open the AMDP class: cl_sd_S4h_stxl_utils=>get_header_text
  • Inside this class, SAP has written the entire logic.

When crafting Table Functions ", in the manner SAP does " consistently adhere to this structure:

Create a CDS Table Function with parameters.

Implement it via an AMDP class/method using native SQLScript.

Consume it in your final CDS view using with parameters.

Follow the exact naming, annotation, and structure shown in standard objects such as I_SalesOrderTP, I_PurchaseOrderTP, I_BillingDocumentTP, etc.

Following this pattern guarantees:

Best performance (native HANA execution)

Transportability and upgrade-safety

Consistency with thousands of standard SAP-delivered objects

Conclusion

It is a tried-and-true architectural best practice to use SAP's standard pattern for CDS Table Functions. You can align your custom developments with the same design principles used in core SAP objects like *I_SalesOrderTP*, *I_PurchaseOrderTP*, and *I_BillingDocumentTP* by defining a CDS Table Function with parameters, implementing its logic in an AMDP method using native SQLScript, and consuming it through a final CDS view.


This method guarantees that sophisticated logic runs directly on SAP HANA for maximum efficiency, stays neatly isolated from the consumption layer, and is resilient to upgrades and transports. More significantly, because it adheres to a well-known and extensively used standard, it makes your solution instantly comprehensible to other SAP developers.

entry.content: Why would you expect the system to translate the subject that is derived from a long text (especially in the cast of long text) in SOST? according to the below note

entry.title: Re: Custom Business configurations for S/4 HANA 2023 private cloud edition: Some tips & Tricks
entry.content:
@michael_smithe5 you can assign each SMBC object to a configuration group. You can then create a filter on configuration group level and save it as a variant. I don't know if you can then create a custom tile that launches the F4579 app with a predefined variant. 
Please also note that the visibility of each SMBC object in F4579 depends on the authorization. If you don't have permission, you won't be able to see it. This way, you can also ensure that different users can see different configuration objects even though they use the same app.

entry.title: Грудень в SAP Community: Актуальні можливості навчання та інноваці
entry.content:
Привіт,  SAP Community Kyiv!

Ділимось із вами низкою важливих вебінарів, ресурсів та інновацій, спеціально розроблених для того, щоб ви залишалися в курсі найважливіших трендів у світі SAP.  Від інновацій у хмарних ERP рішеннях до практичних інструментів оптимізації та нових можливостей в AI — вибір різноманітний.

📚Нова e-book: «A Guide to License, Consumption and Adoption Tools»

У SAP опублікували практичний посібник, який допоможе вам отримати прозорість над ліцензуванням, використанням та впровадженням нових функціональностей.

e-book — це незамінний ресурс для:

  • Менеджерів ліцензування — для контролю витрат та оптимізації портфеля

  • IT директорів — для забезпечення раціонального використання рішень SAP

  • Аналітиків впровадження — для вимірювання успіху adotion ініціатив

За більш детальним контекстом та обговоренням рекомендуємо прочитати блог-пост на SAP Community.

Інструменти підтримки та навігації
